items.title: City Setting, but Village Mentalities
items.abstract: The protest movement that has sprung up in Delhi after a brutal rape in December is largely a lament of the city against a nation that has blamed attacks on women on the women's own modernity.

items.title: What Constitutes Good and Bad Web Design?
items.abstract: Well-crafted sites need to fulfill their functions efficiently and engagingly.

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: Record Number of Misconduct Complaints Are Made Against City School Employees
items.abstract: The office of the Special Commissioner of Investigation handled 4,173 complaints, more than double the amount received during the first year of the Bloomberg administration.

items.title: Engineers Bring Processes of Nature to Design
items.abstract: Morphogenesis, from the Greek words morphê, for shape and genesis, for creation, refers to imitating evolution in developing designs.

items.title: ‘The Geography of Genius,’ by Eric Weiner
items.abstract: A tour of some of the world’s exceptional places.
keywords: The Geography of Genius: A Search for the World's Most Creative Places From Ancient Athens to Silicon Valley (Book)

items.title: In Rural Alabama, a Longtime Mistrust of Medicine Fuels a Tuberculosis Outbreak
items.abstract: Marion, Ala., is in the throes of a tuberculosis outbreak so severe that it has posted an incidence rate that is about 100 times greater than the state’s and worse than many developing countries.

items.title: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
items.abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.

items.title: Review: City Ballet Celebrates Balanchine and Heeds Mother Nature
items.abstract: The storm caused the company to cancel Saturday’s performance, an unfortunate interruption of momentum built in the first week of its winter season.

items.title: MoMA PS1 Names Winner of Summer Architecture Competition
items.abstract: Escobedo Solíz Studio, a partnership based in Mexico City, will transform the museum’s courtyard this summer.

items.title: Students in Rural America Ask, ‘What Is a University Without a History Major?’
items.abstract: Financial and enrollment woes at schools like the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point have led to a scramble for fixes, such as dropping longstanding liberal arts degrees.

items.title: The Met Opera Has a Gay Conductor. Yes, That Matters.
items.abstract: Openly gay performing arts leaders are still rare. So it was a breath of fresh air to chat about coming out and Celine Dion with Yannick Nézet-Séguin and his partner.

items.title: How Bauhaus Redefined What Design Could Do for Society
items.abstract: A century after its founding, the German school of art and architecture remains one of the most transcendent — and frustrating — movements of the Modernist age.

items.title: Long Live Eccentric English Design
items.abstract: Uninterested in disciplined minimalism, a group of defining interior designers is championing England’s long-held preference for color, wit and wackiness.

items.title: Bringing Nature Back to the Urban Core
items.abstract: Our photographers set out to explore three cities that are seeking to restore their connection to nature by reclaiming land for green space.

items.title: ‘Attempted Security Threat’ Disables Software at Some New York Schools
items.abstract: The outage in a platform used by teachers and students has caused another disruption for a system that has had its share amid the pandemic.
keywords: Goldstein, Leon M, High School for the Sciences (Brooklyn, NY)

items.title: In New York City Sewage, a Mysterious Coronavirus Signal
items.abstract: For the past year, scientists have been looking for the source of strange coronavirus sequences that have appeared in the city’s wastewater.

items.title: Cooper Hewitt Design Museum Gets a New Director
items.abstract: Maria Nicanor, an architecture curator and historian, takes on the Smithsonian position held by Caroline Baumann, who in 2020 was abruptly forced to resign.

items.title: Celebrating Black History Month? These 5 Cities Are Going All Out
items.abstract: Honoring all things African-American, with performances, river cruises, exhibitions and more, in Richmond, Va., Portland, Ore., Philadelphia, Cleveland and San Antonio.

items.title: A Million More Trees for New York City: Leaders Want a Greener Canopy
items.abstract: The city’s five borough presidents are also urging the mayor to honor a pledge to spend 1 percent of the municipal budget on parks.
